Hi,
   I've updated the setState_HP(), setState_UV(), setState_SP(), and
se=
tState_SV() routines in the CVS version of Cantera to use a root
finder alg=
orithm rather than a Newton's method. There's a new test
problem, CpJump, t=
hat demonstrates that the new  algorithm can handle
jumps in Cp and H at te=
mperature boundaries. The old algorithm could not
handle these jumps. I hop=
e this helps your application.

Best wishes,
Harry Moffat

e!! Error: no convergence. dt =3D
0.000219057

Hi,
   Since the entropy and=
 enthalpy are monotonic functions of T, I could
probably change the solutio=
n algorithm to a root finder algorithm rather
than the Newton's method that=
 is currently being employed. Newton's
method rigorously requires that the =
first derivative be continuous for
convergence to be achieved. This in turn=
 requires that Cp and H and/or S
be continuous at temperature boundaries. T=
his is normally the case, and
a warning message is printed out if it isn't =
the case. However, the
question then becomes to what degree are these funct=
ions continuous
across temperature boundaries and can one then make a state=
ment about
how "continuous" they have to be in order for the setState_HP an=
d
setState_SP functions to converge for all cases. 
   A root finder algori=
thm has less requirements on the smoothness of
the function than a Newton's=
 method algorithm. So, it should be more
robust.

   Also, I could expose t=
he convergence requirements for these two
functions in the matlab levels. C=
urrently, they are exposed at the C++
level with defaults on dT of 1.0E-4.
=

Best wishes,
Harry Moffat

Subject: [cantera] CANTERA Roulette!! Error: no conv=

0.000219057

Procedure: setState_SP
Error:   no convergence=
. dt =3D 0.000219057

I feel like my research has become a game of roulette=
!  I am using
Cantera  from within Matlab, where I solve systems of compres=
sors and
turbines.  It works great most of the time!  However when my code =
asks
Cantera to setState_SP (entropy and Pressure) or set_State_HP and this=

state fall sufficiently close to 1000K, Cantera crashes.  I know I could
f=
udge my quarry in the hopes I don't land on a 1000K condition but I
would r=
ather know my code (and Cantera) are rock stable.

I believe this is happen=
ing because of the NASA polynomials switching
coefficients at 1000K, and wh=
ile the polynomials are close to each
other, the setState function requires=
 10^-8 accuracy (way more than I
require).

I am hoping someone else has so=
lved this problem or can offer
assistance.   
My current thought is to find=
 the function(s) where the polynomial  
coefficients are chosen for the app=
ropriate temperature range.   Then
add
a case such that between T =3D 999 a=
nd 1001 a new polynomial will be  
interpolated and used for the subsequent=
 thermo calculations.   
Unfortunately I have yet to find which functions t=
hese are and deduce if
this may really work/help?

Your help will be greatl=
y appreciated,
Winston Burbank
ftwsb@...
